001-techniques/timelines/01-timelines-ov.title: 01 Timelines - Overview
001-techniques/timelines/01-timelines-ov.description:
Showing the passage of time, events, structures, etc. in the form of a timeline provides visual information for something which is hard to grasp, quite abstract and arbitrary.
The first timelines appeared in the time of enlightenment, when scholars started to assemble vast amounts of data and felt a strong need to organise and order this data.How do we define that something is “antique” or “medieval”?
→ Time frames: Periods
How could periods be defined?
Definition: A period is a stretch of time with relatively stable characteristics in arts and architecture, material use, human lifestyle, political systems, etc.

headers.heading: The Big Periods of the Western World on a Timeline

101-prehistory/i.-humans-and-societies.h.title: I. Humans and Societies
101-prehistory/i.-humans-and-societies.h.description:
What makes us humans? Is it upright walking? Art? Language? ...? How do the following images illustrate and date possible indicators of "being human"? Image Ardipithecus Ramidus, "Ardi". Humanoid walking upright, 4.4 million years ago
Image Hand axe found in the Olduvai gorge, Tanzania, ~1.2 million years old. British Museum
Image Cave paintings in the cave of Chauvet, Ardèche, Southern France, 32.000–35.000 years old.
Image Wild horse made of mammoth ivory, 32.000 years old, 4.8 cm long, Vogelherd cave, Schwäbische Alb, Germany
Image "Venus of Willendorf", a female figurine, limestone, 11 cm, Willendorf, Germany, c. 29.000 years old People made art. What can this tell us about them and their society? What do people need in order to be able to make art? What does a society need to look like if people in it can make art?
cooperation myths

102-early-civilisations/i.-farming-and-t.title: I. Farming and the Emergence of Complex Societies
102-early-civilisations/i.-farming-and-t.description: What is farming? how did people provide for food before farming? less supervisioncheap to keepdigest cellulosepull plows → more farmlandgive hides, meat & milknew source of energyfaster communication→bigger empiresmore mobile armies Recompilebetter hunting and gathering technology (sickles, baskets)EffectsWhy in Eurasia?Warmer, wetter climate (c. 10.000 BC) →Wild grains spread in Middle EastEurasia's East-West axis: plants share same climate and seasonal variations of sunlightDomestic crops and intensive agriculture can spread rapidly from one centerAgriculture develops first in Fertile Crescent becauseCities and civilisations can develop and spread rapidly from one centerPermanent villages with stable grain supplies which allowRising population →Need more food, but won't abandon easier hunter-gatherer lifestyle →Casual agriculture mixed more on agricultureDevelop new agricultural techniques:2-field system, crop rotation → population growsLess cooperation and sharing →Private property→social classes andmore conflict→Start of status 102-early-civilisations/iii.-consequence.title: III. Consequences of Agriculture
102-early-civilisations/iii.-consequence.description:
What might be consequences of people beginning to farm?Negative Feedback Loop
Perennial Wheatgrass vs. Annual Wheat Comparison of the root systems of Perennial Wheatgrass and Annual Wheat. This difference is important e.g. in the midwest of the USA, where the perennial wheatgrass was predominant and only replaced in the 19th and early 20th centuries. → what do you think consequences might be for soil and landscape after farmers started planting annual wheat instead of the perennial wheatgrass? Explain the difference between the two sorts of wheat illustrated above and try to think about consequences perennial wheatgrass: doesn’t die after the season; hibernates → massive roots annual wheat: dies after season; seeds off annual grasses: had bigger seeds → bigger yield → loss of root systems: more erosion, wind and water cary away most important top soil strati; flash floods, dust storms

102-early-civilisations/ii.-neolithiciza.title: II. Neolithicization, or Mesolithic-Neolithic transition
102-early-civilisations/ii.-neolithiciza.description:
Reading tasks mark/highlight important words and concepts define the words (monolingual dictionary) translate only if absolutely necessary! → help each other, feel free to quietly discuss in pairs! integrate text and flowcharts! Are there differences? Definitions Mesolithic: meso: middle. lithos: stone. Neolithic: neo: new/young. Timeline of Prehistory Dates ~70 000 – 10 000 BC Ice-Ages impede spread of humans in Europe, Northern Asia and North America ~31 900 years ago Modern humans live in South-Eastern Europe ~13 000 BC Earliest settlements in North America. Presumably via Bering strait and Alaska from Siberia ~9000 First sheep-herding (Mesopotamia) First use of non-regional crops (North Syria) First Ceramics in China ~8000 First domestication of the pig (Asia) ~7000 Agriculture in Middle and South America ~5500 First domestication of the horse ~5400 First farmers come to Middle Europe ~4500 First usage of plough (Mesopotamia) ~3200 Maize/corn becomes most important staple food in South America Scholars generally agree that foragers (hunter-gatherers) of the Paleolithic enjoyed, at least much of the time, sufficient food supplies, adequate shelter, and shorter daily working hours than most adults do today. Humans did not, therefore, consciously take up crop growing and animal raising because they thought they would have a more secure and satisfying life. In other words, humans seem to have been “pushed” into agriculture rather than “pulled” into it.The coming of agrarian societies was almost certainly connected to the waning of the Pleistocene, or Ice Age, that is, the period, beginning about 15 000 years ago, when glaciers shrank and both sea levels and global temperatures rose. In several parts of the Northern Hemisphere rainfall increased significantly. Rising seas drowned low-lying coastal shelves as well as land bridges that had previously connected regions separated by water today. Land bridges now under water included spans between Siberia and Alaska, Australia and Papua New Guinea, and Britain and continental Europe. One consequence of the great thaw was that across much of the Northern Hemisphere warmer, rainier, ice-free conditions permitted forests, meadowlands, and small animal populations to flourish. The natural bounty was so great in some localities that human bands began to settle in one place all or part of the year to forage and hunt. That is, they became sedentary, settled in hamlets or villages rather than moving from camp to camp. For example, in the relatively well-watered part of the Middle East we call the Fertile Crescent, groups began sometime between 10 000 and 13 000 years ago to found tiny settlements in order to collect plentiful stands of wild grain and other edible plants and animals.
The Fertile Crescent
In time, these groups learned how to control and manipulate the reproduction of plants that were bigger, tastier, more nutritious, and easier to grow, harvest, store, and cook than were wild food plants. Systematic domestication was under way! In the Fertile Crescent key domesticates included the ancestors of wheat, barley, rye, and several other edible plants. Selecting and breeding particular animals species – sheep, goats, cattle, pigs – that were good to eat and easy to manage occurred in a similar way. In effect, humans started grooming the natural environment to reduce the organisms they did not want (weeds, predatory wolves) and to increase the number of organisms they did want (grains, legumes, wool-bearing sheep, hunting dogs).The intensification in population densities and economic productivity that farming permitted also led humans to intervene in the natural and physical environment as never before. As farmers cleared more land, planted more crops, and pastured more animals, they enhanced their species’ biological success. That is, there occurred a positive feedback cycle of ever-increasing population and productivity. Beginning about 6000 BC, this intensification in particular parts of the world moved to a level that required radical innovations in the way humans lived and worked. |
www.wolrdhistoryforusall.sds.edu (adapted and shortened by RöM)after reading Sum up the factors that made sedentary lifestyle possible! Define: pull factor / push factors How did humans influence their environment, and how were they influenced by their own development?
Linear Pottery culture (5500–4500 BC)
Bell-Beaker culture (2800–1800BC)
Megalith Culture
Dolmen du Mané-Rutual (Carnac) Stone Circle at Stonehenge (from around 3000 BC)

102-early-civilisations/iv.-cities-and-c.title: IV. Cities and Civilisations
102-early-civilisations/iv.-cities-and-c.description:
Task Find out what the pictures below show

First in the Tigris-Euphrates and Nile River valleys, then the Indus valley, and later in China’s Huang River (Huang He) valley and a few other regions, societies emerged that were far larger and denser than the farming communities of the Neolithic period. We refer to these big concentrations of people as complex societies, or, more traditionally, as civilisations. Their most noticeable characteristic was cities. Early cities were centres of power, manufacturing, and creativity. Building and preserving them, however, required drastic alteration s of the local environment to produce sufficient food, building materials, and sources of energy. The price of this intervention was high. Dense urban societies were extremely vulnerable to changes in weather, climate, disease conditions, wood supplies, and trade links to distant regions. After the appearance of complex societies, humans stepped up their efforts to manipulate and control their physical and natural environment. This had great benefits but also produced a negative feedback cycle.Dates Among the oldest cities are • Jericho (fortified ~8000) • Çatal Hüyük (~7000) •Ur (~5000) • Byblos (5th millennium) ~5700 First proto-urban architecture in Egypt ~5500 Neolithical settlements with long houses in Middle Europe ~4600 First city-like settlements in the Indus valley ~4300 to ~800 BC Stilt house settlements in central Europe ~3800 Cultures in China organized in cities ~3300 Glacier man “Ötzi” ~3100 to ~2600 Stonehenge ~3000 Sumerian city-states ~2600 – 1800 Mohenjo-Daro in the Indus valley, systematically planned city The intensification of population and production obliged humans to experiment with new forms of social organization. The customs and rules that governed social relationships in a foraging band of twentyfive or thirty people were no longer adequate.After about 4000 BC, massive changes occur in social customs and institutions. The complex societies that arose in the Tigris-Euphrates, Nile, and Indus valleys, and somewhat later in other regions, were cauldrons of intensification. That is, people lived and worked together in much larger, denser communities than had ever existed. These societies shared a number of fundamental characteristics, which we generally associate with civilizations: Cities arose, the early ones varying somewhat in their forms and functions. By 2250 BC, there were about eight cities in the world that had 30 000 or more inhabitants. By 1200 BC there were about sixteen cities that big. Some people took up full-time specialized occupations and professions (artisans, merchants, soldiers, priests, and so on) rather than spending most of their time collecting, producing, or processing food. A hierarchy of social classes (social stratification) appeared in which some men and women – the elite class – had more wealth, power, and privilege than did others. Also, men became dominant over women in political and social life, leading to patriarchy. The state, that is, a centralized system of government and command, was invented. This meant that a minority group – kings, queens, high officials, priests, generals – exercised control over the labour and social behaviour of everyone else. Complex exchanges of food and other products took place within the complex society, and lines of trade connected the society to neighbours near and far. Technological innovations multiplied, and each new useful invention tended to suggest several others. Monumental building took place – city walls, temples, palaces, public plazas, and tombs of rulers. A system of writing, or at least a complex method of record-keeping, came into use. Spiritual belief systems, public laws, and artistic expressions all became richer and more complex.
Creative individuals collaborated with the ruling class to lay the foundations of astronomy, mathematics, and chemistry, as well as civil engineering and architecture. Dates (see as timeline) ~3000 Parallel development of cuneiform in Mesopotamia and hieroglyphs in Egypt ~2980 First unification of Upper and Lower Egypt (Old Kingdom) ~2650 – 2190 Time of the Pyramids ~2650 First step pyramid by Snofru ~2600 Cheops pyramid 2600 – ~1425 Minoan culture on Crete ~1900 – 1531 Babylonian Empire ~1700 Code of Hammurabi, earliest known law code ~1600 Mycenaean Culture, earliest advanced civilization on mainland Europe ~1000 – 70 BC Kingdom of Israel (with interruptions) 30 BC Death of the last pharaoh, Cleopatra VII. Egypt becomes a Roman province A society did not have to have every one of these characteristics to qualify as a civilization. The checklist is less important than the fact that all these social, cultural, economic, and political elements interacted dynamically with one another. The synergism among them made the society complex, that is, made it recognizable as a civilization.World population started growing at a faster rate than ever before. The size and density of communities expanded, and networks of communication by land and sea became more extensive and sophisticated. Along with these developments came, as we might well expect, an intensification in the flow of information and a general speed-up in the accumulation of knowledge of all kinds. One example is religious knowledge. In the early millennia of this period certain ideas, practices, and artistic expressions centred on the worship of female deities spread widely along routes of trade and migration to embrace a large part of western Eurasia. Another example is the idea and technology of writing, which emerged first, as far as we know, in either Egypt or Mesopotamia and spread widely from there to the eastern Mediterranean and India. A third example is the horse-drawn chariot, which may have first appeared in the Inner Eurasian steppes and within less than a thousand years spread all across Eurasia from western Europe to China.There were numerous scientific, technological, and cultural innovations that complex societies achieved. To take just one early example, the city-dwellers of Sumer in southern Mesopotamia, which is as far as we know the earliest urban civilization, made fundamental scientific and technical breakthroughs in the fourth and third millennia BC. Sometime before 3000 BC, Sumerian scribes worked out a system of numerical notation in the writing script they used, called cuneiform. They used a combination of base-ten and base-sixty mathematics, together with a growing understanding of geometry, for everyday government and commerce, as well as to survey land, chart the stars, design buildings, and build irrigation works. Other technical innovations included the seed drill (a sowing device), the vaulted arch, refinements in bronze metallurgy, and, most ingenious of all, the wheel. This concept was probably first applied to pottery making, later to transport and ploughing.Within complex societies, such as those that emerged in the great river valleys, the interchange of information and ideas tended to be so intense that each society developed a distinct cultural style. We can tell apart these distinctive styles today in the surviving remnants of buildings, art objects, written texts, tools, and other material remains. We should, however, keep two ideas in mind. One is that all complex societies were invariably changing, rather than possessing timeless, static cultural traits. The style of a civilization changed from one generation to the next because cultural expressions and values were invariably bound up with the natural environment, economic life, and politics, which were continuously changing as well. The second point is that early civilizations were not culturally self-contained. All of them developed and changed as they did partly because of their connections to other societies near and far, connections that played themselves out in trade, migration, war, and cultural exchange. |
Well watered farmlandsBirth of agricultureDomest. of animalsSemi-arid grasslandscoexistenceSettled farmersNomadic herdersPeaceful trade and service in civilized armies → Nomads learn their military techniquescivilisation usually wins until weakened by natural or human factors (e.g., poor leadership)Peaceful trade and service in civilized armies → Nomads learn about & envy civilized wealthcivilisations adapted to infectious diseases but nomads haven'tclashIndian civilisation spreads across South & Sout-East AsiaMesopotamic civilisation spreads to Middle East and GreeceGreek civilisation spreads to Rome and MacedonRoman civilizaztion spreads to Western EuropeChinese civilisation spreads across East and South-East AsiaNOMADS:• Meat → Bigger and stronger• More mobile → Hard to catch• Size & speed → Psychological edgecivilisation:• Agr. → Bigger population and army• More org. & disciplined army• Usually better equip. & tech.Sometimes peaceful co-existence, but often clashes with each side having its own advantages1civilisation revives and expands → Clashes with new nomadic tribescivilisation falls and continues to decline because nomads can't or won't maintain itcivilisation starts to revive for several reasons:Further weakens civilizizationsNomadic hit-and-run raids- Nomads get attached to civilized comforts- Nomads marry civ. women who raise the children- Nomads learn to appreciate & maintain civ. Recompile

headers.heading: Complex societies as centres of innovation
Farmers, Nomads, and the Spread of Civilisation

102-early-civilisations/v.-repetition-ch.title: V. Repetition chapters 101 and 102
102-early-civilisations/v.-repetition-ch.description:
Repetition block 1 What is history / prehistory?
What is a period / epoch?
What is domestication? When did farming start? Why did people start farming?
How did humans influence their environment, and how were they influenced by their own development? Repetition block 2 Repeat and sum up the features of early civilizations
Social customs and institutions changed greatly with the formation of early complex societies. Describe general characteristics of complex societies
How do you expect the personal lifestyle of an individual or a family to have changed from a nomadic to a sedentary lifestyle in an early city (speculate!) How did religions support the development of early complex societies? – What other fictions do you think played (and still play) important roles in societies?
What role does constant change play in (early) societies?

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
